comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: G-ABXY www.portmarnockwaves.com/Hearts_Content.html

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content:
So, a memento of Jim Mollison's East West crossing of the Atlantic at the start of which he took off from The Velvet Strand, Portmarnock. The De Havilland Puss Moth was named 'The Heart's Content'. Mollison was married to Amy Johnson the famous aviiatrix who accompanied him to Ireland for the start of his flight. Amy's famous airplane was named 'Jason' and while they were waiting for good weather to allow Mollison to take-off they attended a reception in the Ballsbridge house of the Fitzsimmons (Publishers - Talbot Press & the Educational Company). At the reception Amy discovered the son of her hosts had the middle name 'Jason', as on her plane. She arranged to take Wilford Jason Fitzsimmons for a flight at the airfield at Kildonan, Finglas - an experience he treasured for the rest of his life.

Jim Mollison took off from Portmarnock in DH Puss Moth 'The Heart's Content' (G-ABXY) on August 18th 1932 and landed at Pennfield Ridge, New Brunswick, 31 hours and 20 minutes later becoming the first person to make a solo crossing of the Atlantic from East to West.

This looks like a memento rather than a model as it has an engraved plaque on it. I believe I have seen the person holding it elsewhere but cannot recall where at present.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Hi Bob. You might be interested to see this souvenir badge [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03/6028910048/in/set-72157627505730085]

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: What a lovely memento of Amy's flight to Australia. Thanks for that, Stu.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: I believe that the person in this photograph is John J Horgan. He may have been a photographer for The Irish Independent at one time although he may only have operated on a free-lance basis for them. In the 1930s and 1950s he built up a reputation as an aviation photographer. In the 1950s he lived at 'Innisrowan', Ballymun Road, Glasnevin, Dublin. I have two reference photographs of him - one taken in 1937 and one taken about 1950/51. In the first he is identifiable as the person in the photograph holding the model of Mollison's Puss Moth. In the second he is much heavier and it would be hard to be sure it is the same person. I have a number of his pictures of Irish aviation but sadly, I believe his important collection of Irish aviation photographs was sold to a Swiss collector about 15-20 years ago.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: I should also say there is a possible link between John J Horgan and Jim Mollison in that he photographed most of the historic flights that took off from Portmarnock. I have several of the photographs he took but not, as it happens, any of Mollison. However, I doubt very much that he was not present on that occasion.

comment.author: 96261063@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Pathe news have several clips of Mollison. Here he is coming in to land at Roosevelt Field USA in the aforementioned aircraft: www.britishpathe.com/video/britains-lindy-aka-jim-molliso... I don't see take off from Portmarnock but they do have one of the Southern Cross taking off there in 1930: www.britishpathe.com/video/the-globe-circled-by-air/query... The locals out here celebrate "Southern Cross Day" in period costumes at the end of June: picasaweb.google.com/gdunne7/SouthernCrossDay
